Kentucky coaches ramp up rivalry's importance

LEXINGTON, Ky. – Rich Brooks has been where Mark Stoops is right now, steadily rebuilding the University of Kentucky football program but in need of a breakthrough victory against rival Louisville. Brooks

Kentucky coaches ramp up rivalry's importance

Kyle Tucker, ktucker@courier-journal.com 10:56 p.m. EST November 26, 2014

Tim Couch completed 36 of 50 passes against the Cardinals in 1997. ``I felt like a little kid in the back yard,” he said.(Photo: &lt;137&gt; C-J file&lt;137&gt;)

CONNECT 2 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

LEXINGTON, Ky. – Rich Brooks has been where Mark Stoops is right now, steadily rebuilding the University of Kentucky football program but in need of a breakthrough victory against rival Louisville.

Brooks lost his first four tries – all against Bobby Petrino, who is back for a second act coaching the Cardinals – and things weren't looking good late in his fifth attempt. Ninth-ranked Louisville scored to take a 34-33 lead with 1:45 to go in the 2007 Governor's Cup game.

As the Wildcats tried to answer, a personal foul on Eric Scott made it first-and-21 with under a minute to go. Brooks remembers he was still stewing over that mistake when, suddenly, wide receiver Steve Johnson came wide open down the left sideline. Quarterback Andre' Woodson found him for a 53-yard winning touchdown with 28 seconds left.

"And everybody went nuts on the sideline," Brooks said. "That was my favorite memory."

RELATED: Himmelsbach | Rivalry began as one-sided affair

RELATED: Ex-U of L players: UK rivalry intense, heated

It launched a memorable season in which Kentucky won eight games, including upsets of eventual national champion LSU and then perennial powerhouse Florida State in a bowl game. It was also the beginning of a four-game Wildcats winning streak in the series.

"It was critically important," Brooks said. "To be able to break through in 2007 was huge."

Woodson, who'd literally fumbled away a chance to tie Louisville with six minutes to go two years earlier, said he and Kentucky desperately needed that win, much like the current Cats after a five-game losing streak has washed away all the positive vibes of a 5-1 start to Stoops' second season.

"You kind of had to feel like: Were we progressing? Did we take a step back?" Woodson said. "But to come away with a win my senior year, that just builds such a confidence in a group. Especially when you start considering how young this team is, just moving forward, if those guys can manage to come away with a victory with this much significance, get themselves back into a bowl game, it's going to do wonders for the program.

"Stoops is in a very similar situation (to what) Brooks was in. You can tell that the transformation of the program is taking place. It's just taking time."

Stoops, who inherited a team coming off a 2-10 season and is 7-16 so far as Kentucky's coach, has been showing his players highlight videos of past Cats-Cards clashes this week to "educate" them on the rivalry and remind them why it's important. Former players have come in to talk about what's on the line Saturday when UK visits U of L.

"We want to embrace that rivalry. We want the kids to be a part of that and know when they come play at Kentucky that Louisville is a big game for us," said Stoops, whose team can clinch its first bowl invitation since 2010 with a win against the Cardinals. "I don't think there should be any lack of motivation for our team."

Offensive coordinator Neal Brown, a Kentucky native and former UK player who was there the day Tim Couch helped the Cats pile up 801 yards and 68 points in a 1998 rivalry rout, has helped lead the educational charge this week.

He made in-state players such as wide receiver Ryan Timmons give a speech to the team about why this game matters.

RELATED: Kentucky's bowl hopes hinge on rivalry game

RELATED: Q&A: UK's Stoops and Eliot preview Louisville

"I'm so excited about rivalry week," Brown said, noting Kentucky's current three-game losing streak in the series. "It's time for us to hold up our end of the bargain."

Brooks believes it is wise for the Cats' coaches to acknowledge the magnitude of the game and emphasize the importance of winning it. Because everyone who supports the program already knows.

"It's a huge, huge game in the state of Kentucky, and the alumni made no bones about it," Brooks said. "They wanted to beat Louisville, no matter what. You got the message as soon as you came into town that this was a huge rivalry."

Woodson calls the football rivalry "ever-growing," admitting that it isn't yet on the same level as when the Cats and Cards collide on the basketball court, "but as the football program just continues to grow, we'll witness the intensity rise to similar heights."\

Kentucky football coach Mark Stoops talked about Saturday's game at Louisville, but declined to say much about whether OC Neal Brown is a candidate to coach Troy.

"All the players and coaches recognize that winning it is vital; bragging rights are a priority," Woodson said. "I think this game has more meaning than postseason play for the state of Kentucky. When I played, in that five-year time frame, we managed to beat LSU, Georgia, FSU and Clemson. And yet, the one game that always seems to stick out with the fan base is the fact that we came away with that Governor's Cup when we beat Louisville in '07. So I think that kind of showcases the significance of this game."

No pressure, Mark Stoops. For the record, Brooks believes in Stoops' rebuilding plan. He would know what a good one looks like, having done it at both Oregon and Kentucky.

"There's no question that he's got the thing headed in the right direction, but he's still a little short on depth of playmakers and having a good, talented senior class so he can get things over the hump," Brooks said. "I think he's very close and he's going to get through it. That's another reason this rivalry game takes on even more significance. That's going to be just one more step in that direction this year."

Kyle Tucker can be reached at (502) 582-4361. Follow him on Twitter @KyleTucker_CJ.
